summary: This is the last will and testament of Jeffrey E. Epstein, executed while he was a resident of St. Thomas, US Virgin Islands. It appoints three primary executors and several successor executors to manage his estate, which is to be transferred to the 'JEFFREY E. EPSTEIN 2017 TRUST'. The document grants extensive powers to the executors for managing, investing, and disposing of estate assets. This is the last will and testament of Jeffrey E. Epstein, executed on June 6, 2017. It details the distribution of his estate, establishes a trust, and includes provisions for tax payments and penalties for beneficiaries who contest the will. The document is signed by Epstein and two witnesses.

events.title: Creation of the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2017 Trust
events.description: The trust agreement referenced in the will as the ultimate beneficiary of Epstein's entire estate was created.

events.title: Execution of Epstein's Will

locations: St. Thomas, United States Virgin Islands
Richmond County (mentioned as where the notary is qualified)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein's last will directs his entire estate to be transferred to the 'JEFFREY E. EPSTEIN 2017 TRUST'.
The will appoints Darren K. Indyke, Richard D. Kahn, and Terje R' '-Larsen as primary executors, with Eva Andersson D In, Kathryn Ruemmler, and Stephen Hanson as successor executors.
Executors are granted extremely broad powers to manage, invest, sell, and even continue operating Epstein's business enterprises without needing court approval.
The will specifies a $250,000 compensation for each executor serving, but prohibits them from engaging in self-dealing transactions with the estate.
Epstein declared himself a resident and domiciliary of St. Thomas, US Virgin Islands, at the time of making the will.
Jeffrey Epstein executed his last will and testament on June 6, 2017, approximately two years before his death.
The will establishes a trust (the 'Trust Agreement') and directs the majority of his estate to be distributed to the trustee(s) of that trust.
It contains a 'no-contest' clause, stating that any beneficiary who challenges the will or trust shall have their provisions nullified.
The document details complex provisions for the payment of federal and state estate taxes, including taxes on assets not directly passing under the will or trust ('Apportionment Assets').
The will was signed in New York County, New York, and notarized by Habibe Avdiu, a notary public qualified in Richmond County.
